\begin{abstract}
We investigate, theoretically and experimentally, 
the properties of diffraction spectra of Fibonacci lattices with arbitrary spacings.
We show that, by means of a suitable composition rule, a Fibonacci sequence can
be mapped into another one with a different lattice spacing. 
In this way we are able to define 
equivalence classes of Fibonacci structures 
and their generators, namely the Fibonacci sequences from which all the 
others can be obtained by compostion rule. 
We show that each class can be characterized
by a given diffraction pattern which is essentially the one
of the generator, 
in the sense that the most prominent
features of this spectrum are common to all the elements of the class.
This theoretical prediction is in good agreement with experimental 
results.
\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}
Since the first experimental proof of the existence 
of solids lacking of translational invariance, nevertheless exhibiting a
discrete Bragg diffraction spectrum \cite{shechtman1984}, the study
of \emph{quasicrystals} attracted quite a lot of attention.
The impact of this discovery on the scientific community was such that
in 1992 the previous definition of "crystal" 
had to be modified in order to include these structures whose diffraction pattern would show long range order
although their spatial distribution lacks translational invariance \cite{senechal1995}. 

This means that the spatial distribution 
of a set of repeated units can be precisely determined, yet avoiding any pattern repetition. 
This is the reason why those structures have been named 
{\it aperiodic} or {\it quasiperiodic} (note that these terms also have a precise mathematical meaning)
to stress their difference with respect to periodic ones.
As a consequence, when it comes to diffraction-like 
phenomena, phase relations between waves scattered by quasiperiodic
structures are much more complicated than their periodic counterpart,
giving rise to a rich and fascinating phenomenology. 
For instance, the reciprocal lattice of a quasiperiodic structure may be 
dense in the wavevector space, allowing new types of scattering and phase 
matching phenomena. 
These properties have stimulated the research of exciting technological
applications especially in optics, such as optical dielectric multilayers
for resonant transmission \cite{Dielectric mirrors 1}, solar energy
harvesting \cite{Solar}, plasmonics \cite{Plasmon,plasmon 2} and nonlinear
optics \cite{Nonlinear,Nonlnear 2}. Dynamical and transport
phenomena in this kind of structures are also radically different compared
to periodic media \cite{phonon,phonon 2,transport}. The interested
reader can refer to some of the available monographies 
(e.g. \cite{optics general,transport general}) for more details. 

Quasiperiodic arrangements can be realized in a large variety of structures
with different properties, but a systematic classification of these orders 
and their related properties is still lacking. 
In one dimension (1D)
the paradigm of a quasicrystal is the 
Fibonacci lattice (FL).
This is a 1D lattice
whose relative distances between two adjacent points belong to the set $\{L,S\}$, standing for Long and Short respectively, 
and are arranged according to a specific
sequence (see below). The two lengths $L$ and $S$ are often chosen such that
$L/S=\tau$, where $\tau=\left(\sqrt{5}+1\right)/2$ is the \emph{golden ratio}. 
Nevertheless it is possible to construct Fibonacci lattices
with $L/S\neq\tau$.
In view of their technological applications 
but also purely from the fundamental point of view,
it is interesting to investigate whether there exists 
any relation between different FLs, 
and how a given geometry determines their physical properties.

One issue worth being addressed is
whether different FLs having arbitrary length ratios,
characterized by the 
quantity $\eta=S/\left(L-S\right)$, 
produce diffraction spectra related to each other, similarly
to what happens in periodic lattices for which a change in the lattice
parameter simply results in an expansion or a contraction
of the spectrum along the wavevector axis. We show
that this is not the case: two FLs having different $\eta$'s produce
in general completely different diffraction spectra 
which are not trivially related by simple rescaling, 
even if the Fibonacci sequence of the $L$ and $S$ segments from which they come, is the same. 

In this paper we show that it 
is possible to group the Fibonacci lattices into \emph{equivalence classes} 
for which the diffraction spectrum is \emph{essentially}
the same up to a proper rescaling. This means that, even if the spectrum
is not exactly the same, the most prominent features are shared by
all FLs belonging to the same class. For each
class it is possible to define a representative lattice whose
diffraction spectrum contains (up to a proper rescaling) the basic ``shape''
of all the spectra belonging to the same class. Our theoretical analysis
is compared with a real case, by performing optical diffraction
measurements on several 1D Fibonacci gratings.
   
\section{Fibonacci lattices and their diffraction pattern}
A Fibonacci string is any word made of two letters, $L$ and $S$, 
obtained by means of the substitution rule $LS\rightarrow L$
and $L\rightarrow S$ starting from the letter $S$. When this procedure
is iterated, we get an infinite string whose initial elements are
$LSLLSLSLLSLLSLSLLSLSL\cdots$. By associating to $L$ and $S$
segments of different lengths $L>S$
on the real line, we obtain a succession of real numbers which hereafter
will be referred to as Fibonacci lattice (FL). Without
loss of generality, we will always assume that lengths are rescaled
such that the length of the segment $S$ is normalized to $1$. 
Therefore it is possible to describe {\it any} FL in terms of the sole 
parameter $\eta=S/(L-S)>0$.

\section{Quantifying the similarity}
The above condition tells us that bright peaks present in the diffraction spectrum of a given sequence will be present also in the spectrum of a sequence obtained by transforming the previous one by the compostion rule, Eq. \ref{eq:fibrinorm}.

We have seen that the concept of
reciprocal lattice can be extended to FL's. However, when it comes
to the study of diffraction spectra, this description is of limited
utility. In fact, in the case of FL's the set of points for which
$I(q,\eta)\neq0$ is dense in $\mathbb{R}$. Thus in principle $I(q,\eta)$
assumes non-vanishing values everywhere in $\mathbb{R}$. For practical
purposes it is more interesting to describe the diffraction spectrum
in terms of the peaks which are significantly close to one, which
will be referred to as ``brightest peaks''. In the following we
will adopt this kind of description to discuss the similarity of diffraction
patterns for a given class of equivalence.
In order to find the set of points in reciprocal
space corresponding to a strong diffracted intensity for a FL, the
following condition on the argument of the exponential in the expression
for the diffraction pattern has to hold:

\begin{eqnarray}
 &  & \imath Q_{h,h'}x_{n}\\
 & = & \imath 2\pi\left(h+\frac{h'}{\tau}\right)n-\imath Q_{h,h'}-\imath\frac{Q_{h,h'}}{\eta}\left\{ \frac{n}{\tau}\right\} \nonumber \\
 & = & \imath 2\pi\left(hn+h'\left(\left\lfloor \frac{n}{\tau}\right\rfloor +\left\{ \frac{n}{\tau}\right\} \right)\right)-\imath Q_{h,h'}-\imath\frac{Q_{h,h'}}{\eta}\left\{ \frac{n}{\tau}\right\} \nonumber \\
 & = & \imath 2\pi\left(hn+h'\left\lfloor \frac{n}{\tau}\right\rfloor \right)-\imath Q_{h,h'}\nonumber\\
 &+&\imath\left(2\pi h'-\frac{Q_{h,h'}}{\eta}\right)\left\{ \frac{n}{\tau}\right\} \stackrel{\text{mod}2\pi}{=}0.\nonumber 
\end{eqnarray}
In the last line the first term contributes with a factor of $2\pi$
times an integer and can thus be neglected whereas the second contributes
with a global phase factor which gives no contribution
to the intensity. Therefore we are left with the condition $\left(2\pi h'-\frac{Q_{h,h'}}{\eta}\right)=0$.

rule several times, the diffraction pattern develops more and more details
and ultimately tends to the diffraction pattern of the canonical FL with
$\eta=\tau$.

\section{Diffraction from Fibonacci gratings and their similarity}
To test experimentally the diffraction from FL's, a series of quasi
- periodic diffraction gratings have been prepared using a photorefractive
direct laser writing (DLW) technique \cite{Scrittura}. This technique
consists in scanning with a focused laser beam a photorefractive sample,
engraving on it a series of lines with a modified refractive index
with respect to the rest of the sample. The scanning movement is performed
by translating the sample with the aid of a computer - controlled
XY stage at constant speed of 50 $\mu m/s$. The nominal precision
of the translation stage is 0.5$\mu m$ for the conditions used in
this experiment. A frequency doubled diode pumped $\textrm{Nd:YWO}_{4}$
solid state laser (Coherent Verdi V5) emitting a CW beam at 532 nm
has been used as light source for DLW. The beam was suitably attenuated
by a series of neutral density filters and sent to a focusing microscope
objective (Olympus 100X/0.80) so that the power after the objective
was set at 17 mW. The substrate used to engrave the optical structures
is a slab of photorefractive lithium niobate doped with iron at the
nominal concentration of 0.1 mol\% in the melt. The sample was X-cut
with dimensions ($\textrm{X}\times\textrm{Y}\times\textrm{Z}$) $1\textrm{mm}\times8\textrm{mm}\times13\textrm{mm}$
and the lines were written on the X face, by scanning along the Y
direction with an ordinarily polarized beam. This process can induce
extraordinary refractive index changes as large as $10^{-3}$in the
written lines and therefore can be used to produce arbitrary diffraction
structures. 
The diffraction pattern of these structures was measured with the
help of a computer - controlled optical diffractometer in which the
sample and the detector were mounted on two co - axial goniometers
that were independently controlled by a computer \cite{Argiolas 2007}.
An optical beam produced by a He-Ne laser at 632.8 nm with a power
of 4 mW was expanded, polarized along the extraordinary direction
and finally transmitted through the sample surface, resulting in a
clearly visible diffraction pattern. This pattern was measured by
a Si photodiode and a lock - in amplifier and recorded on the computer
as a function of the detector and of the sample angle.
In order to compare the experimental data with the theoretical calculation
we need to take into account that our gratings are made up of a (quasi)
periodic repetition of a region with a modified refractive index,
$\Delta n(x)$. This leads to the fact, well known from standard diffraction
theory, that the diffracted intensity in reciprocal space is proportional
to the product of two terms: a first one, $S(q)$=$\left|\int\Delta n(x)e^{\imath xq}dx\right|^{2}$
which depends on the detailed structure of the repeated unit of the
grating (\emph{structure factor}) and a second term due to lattice
geometry, which is the true object of this study (see Eq. (\ref{eq:theodiff-1})):

Let us now consider the equivalence class $[\eta_{0}]$ and in particular
the sequence $x_{n}^{\eta_{0}}$. Using the continued fraction notation
we can write a sequence of rational approximants to $\eta_{0}=[a_{0},a_{1},a_2,
\cdots]$
as $a_{0}$, $\frac{a_{1}a_{0}+1}{a_{1}}$, $\frac{a_{2}(a_{1}a_{0}+1)+a_{0}}{a_{2}a_{1}+1}$, etc. 
This helps in identifying the values of $h$ and $h'$ at which the
brightest peaks appear. 
It is worth stressing that whenever $\eta_{0}$ is a rational number ($\eta_{0}=a/b$, with $a,b\in\mathbb{N}$)
$h$ and $h'$ can be chosen such that $h/h'=a/b=\eta_0$. 
Thus, at points $q_m=Q(ma,mb)=2m\pi$ ($m\in\mathbb{Z}$)
we have that $I(q_m,\eta_{0})=1$.
On the other hand, when $\eta_{0}$ is irrational and the condition is never satisfied exactly. Nevertheless we can still resort to the rational approximants
of $\eta_{0}$ to estimate the positions at which the brightest peaks
appear. At lowest order, from eq. (\ref{eq:condBPKs}), we can take
$h=a_{0}h'$, and the corresponding reciprocal space points are approximately
$Q(a_{0}h',h')=2\pi a_{0}h'(1+1/(a_{0}\tau))/d_{1}$. The higher the
order of the approximants used to estimate $\eta_{0}$, the better
the precision in the determination of the brightest peaks' positions.

Let us now turn to the relation between the positions of the brightest
peaks in the diffraction pattern of two lattices belonging to the
same equivalence class. 
Given the two Fibonacci lattices $x_{n}^{\eta_{0}}$ and $\mathcal{C}(x_{n}^{\eta_{0}})=\eta_{1}x_{n}^{\eta_{1}}$
and their associated reciprocal lattices $Q_{0}(h,h')=2\pi d_{0}^{-1}(h+h'/\tau)$,
$Q_{1}(k,k')=2\pi d_{1}^{-1}(k+k'/\tau)$ respectively, where $d_{i}=1+1/(\eta_{i}\tau)$
we define $h_{n}\;\;(k_{n})$ and $h_{n}'\;\;(k_{n}')$ as the numerator
and denominator of the $n-th$ rational approximants of $\eta_{0}\;\;(\eta_{1})$,
the following relations hold true $k_{n}=h_{n}+h_{n}'$ and $k_{n}'=h_{n}$.
By inserting these relations into the expression for $Q_{1}(k,k')$
we get:

\begin{eqnarray}
Q_{1}(k_{n},k_{n}') & = & \frac{2\pi}{d_{1}}\left(k_{n}+\frac{k_{n}'}{\tau}\right)\label{eq:newbrightspot}
   = \frac{2\pi}{d_{1}}\left(h_{n}+h_{n}'+\frac{h_{n}}{\tau}\right)\nonumber \\
 & = & \frac{2\pi\tau}{d_{1}}\left(h_{n}+\frac{h_{n}'}{\tau}\right)
   = \frac{d_{0}\tau}{d_{1}}\frac{2\pi}{d_{0}}\left(h_{n}+\frac{h_{n}'}{\tau}\right)\nonumber \\
 & = & \frac{d_{0}\tau}{d_{1}}Q_{0}(h_{n},h_{n}')=\eta_{1}Q_{0}(h_{n},h_{n}')\nonumber 
\end{eqnarray}
where in the last line we used the fact that $d_{0}\tau/d_{1}=\eta_{1}$.
By defining $h_{n}\;\;(k_{n})$ and $h_{n}'\;\;(k_{n}')$ as the numerator
and denominator of the $n-th$ rational approximants of $\eta_{0}\;\;(\eta_{1})$,
the following relations hold true: $k_{n}=h_{n}+h_{n}'$ and $k_{n}'=h_{n}$.
Therefore we can relate the positions of the brightest peaks of the
two sequences. Let us set $k=k_{n}p$ and $k'=k_{n}'p$ in order to
have $k/k'\approx\eta_{1}$ and thus satisfy condition (\ref{eq:condBPKs})
within an arbitrarily small error. The position of the brightest peaks are then related as
$Q_{1}(k_{n},k_{n}')=\eta_{1}Q_{0}(h_{n},h_{n}')$.
Thus the brightest diffraction peaks of the FL $x_{n}^{\eta_{1}}$
appear at the same reciprocal space positions of those of the FL
$x_{n}^{\eta_{0}}$ properly rescaled by $\eta_{1}$.

\section{Quantifying the similarity}
The above condition tells us that bright peaks present in the diffraction spectrum of a given sequence will be present also in the spectrum of a sequence obtained by transforming the previous one by the compostion rule, Eq. \ref{eq:fibrinorm}. 
However this does not exclude that other (bright) peaks 
can appear in the new diffraction pattern which are not present in the spectrum of the parent sequence.
Nevertheless, it happens that for two FL's to be linked by the composition
rule is not only a sufficient but also a necessary condition to have
similar diffraction spectra. In order to quantify this aspect we use the Kullback-Leibler
(KL) divergence, a quantity useful to compare the degree of similarity
of two distributions (normalized to unity over a common support).

\section{Conclusions}
In conclusion, we investigated the diffraction spectra of FL's in the general case
where $\eta=S/\left(L-S\right)\neq\tau$. 
We showed that even if, generally speaking, lattices with different $\eta$
give diffraction spectra that cannot be rescaled to the same one,
two lattices having lengths $L\;\;(L')$ and $S\;\;(S')$ related
by the composition rule $LS\rightarrow L'$ and $L\rightarrow S'$
have diffraction spectra that share their most prominent diffraction
features (upon rescaling). From this observation we conclude that
the correct way to relate FL's to their diffraction spectra is by
mean of equivalence classes, i.e. subsets of all possible lattices
linked together by the compostion rule. Experimental observations
match well with these previsions.

Since diffraction is a prototype phenomenon in which the phase relationship
between the differently scattered waves play a crucial role, we believe
that our observations may be useful also for the description of analogous
phenomena related to the exchange of momentum between an aperiodic
Fibonacci lattice and a wavefield.

The structure factor modulates the intensity of the lattice diffraction
pattern, complicating the comparison between experiments and theory.
In principle $S(q)$ could be calculated by knowing the details of
the refractive index profile changes produced by our technique. Here
we used another approach which exploits the fact our samples differ
only for the line position sequence $x_{n}$. We can use therefore
the periodic grating (Fig. \ref{fig:per23}) to measure the function
$S(q)$ directly at the reciprocal lattice points $\{q_{M}^{i}\}$
of the periodic grating, where $I(q_{M}^{i})$ has local maxima.
